body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Happens with 7.2.2, doesn't happen with 6.x

Linux Host -> Windows Host over SSH
`ssh -n -o myaccount@windowserver "pwsh.exe c:\mydir\basicscript.ps1"`
The basicscript.ps1 simply 
`write-output "foo"`

returns:
`$'foo\r'`


### Expected behavior

```console
Expected output
foo
```


### Actual behavior

```console
returns:
`$'foo\r'`
```


### Error details

```console
Powershell returns no error
```


### Environment data

```powershell
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.14393
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

_No response_

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
I cannot seem to replicate this, the output seems to be returning just fine. Can you share the following:

* What's the sshd version on the Windows host?

```powershell
$service =  Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_Service -Filter "PathName LIKE '%sshd.exe%'"
(Get-Item -Path $service.PathName.Trim('"')).VersionInfo | Select FileVersion, ProductVersion, FileName
```

* What's your `DefaultShell` set to for ssh, is it cmd, powershell, pwsh, something else?

```powershell
Get-ItemPropertyValue -Path HKLM:\SOFTWARE\OpenSSH -Name DefaultShell
# If prop does not exist it will be cmd
```

* What's the shell of the Linux host, are you just running this from bash, pwsh, something else?

* Do you have anything set in `~/.ssh/config` for the Windows host you are connecting to?

* Does running this work fine `ssh username@server "pwsh -Command '\"foo\"'"` - just trying to rule out some file encoding setup?

I'm also curious what the `-n -o` arguments are meant to be for. I can see `-n` refers to setting stdin to `/dev/null` but `-o` usually needs to be set with an actual option rather than signifying something by itself.
